questions.question:
Question 1: A 9-month-old boy was brought to the well-baby clinic for routine immunization. He has a 
weight for height less than 2 standard deviations below the median. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. • High weight-for-height indicates overweight. • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of 
long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. • Low weight for the age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between 
wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance. Note: Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening 
wasting in children. 122 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A child is brought to the OPD for regular follow-up. Which of the following anthropometric 
record would prompt you to suspect a diagnosis of moderate malnutrition?

options.b: Weight for height < -2 SD to > -3 SD
options.d: Weight for height +2 SD to +3 SD

questions.explanation:
An anthropometric score of Weight for height < -2 to > -3 SD indicates moderate 
malnutrition. The indicators of undernutrition include:

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is an age-independent index?
questions.explanation:
All the indices listed, namely, Kanawati and Mclaren index, Jellife ratio, and Rao and Singh 
index, are age-independent indices. Age-independent indices: 123 
Sold by @itachibot • Kanawati and Mclaren index: Mid-arm circumference/Head circumference • Jellife Ratio: Head circumference/Chest circumference • Rao and Singh Index: Weight (kg) × 100/height2 (cm) • Dugdale Index: Weight (kg)/height1.6 (cm)

questions.question:
Question 4: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the 
WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: 117 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any 
of the following: • Weight-for-length (or height) below 3 SD of the median WHO child growth standards. • Presence of bipedal edema • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm Once the child is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition, the doctor must assess for severe 
edema (+++); low appetite (failed appetite test); medical complications (severe anemia, 
pneumonia, diarrhea, dehydration, cerebral palsy, tuberculosis, HIV, heart disease, etc.) and one 
or more danger signs as per IMNCI If any of the complications are present, the child is diagnosed with complicated SAM and is 
managed inpatient in the facility. If the above-mentioned signs are absent, the child is diagnosed with uncomplicated 
SAM and supervised management at home is given.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are an intern evaluating a 2-year-old girl child for malnutrition. The measurement with 
the WHO standard mid-upper-arm-circumference (MUAC) tape shows yellow. This reading 
would correspond to?
questions.explanation:
The yellow colour on the new WHO standard mid-upper arm circumference of (MUAC) tape 
correlates to a MUAC of 11.5 to 12.5 cm. MUAC tape cut-offs: Colo 
ur Indication Measurement 
s Red 
< 11.5 cm 
Severe Acute Malnutrition (S 
AM) 11.5 to 12.5 c 
m Under-nourished Yello 
w > 12.5 cm 
Normal Gree 
n 124 
Sold by @itachibot Mid-upper arm circumference is used in children between 6 to 60 months. It is measured between 
the acromion and olecranon process and is an age-independent parameter. Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition: Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow. QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - Mid-upper arm circumference/ Height of child Skinfold thickness: It is an age-independent parameter. Routinely, we measure the 
triceps skinfold thickness. It is measured with the help of Harpenden calliper. • Normal: 10 mm • Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm

questions.question:
Question 6: A young child is brought to you for a general check-up. The physician is examining as shown 
below in the image. What would be the cut-off to label the child as malnourished?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the measurement of skinfold thickness using Harpenden calipers. The cut-off to 
label the child as malnourished would be the triceps skinfold thickness value of less than 6mm. 
This is an age-independent parameter. Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition: Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow. QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - mid-upper arm circumference/ height of child.

questions.question:
Question 7: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been 
fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low 
serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a child with a swollen belly, dull face with hypoproteinemia along 
with poor diet history suggests the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. 125 
Sold by @itachibot Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. In 
edematous malnutrition, the initial appearance of edema is commonly observed in the feet and 
lower legs, progressing into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face. The skin over 
the swollen areas may show dark, crackled, peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin 
underneath, making it susceptible to infections. There may be sparse and easily pluckable hair. Hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration is a common 
finding. Associated symptoms of misery, apathy, and loss of appetite are seen in children with 
edema. Other options: Option B: Marasmus is a severe form of wasting characterized by significant loss of fat and muscle 
tissue as the body utilizes these resources for energy. It is often triggered by acute starvation or 
illness in individuals with borderline nutritional status. Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a chronic liver disease that affects infants and young 
children. Common symptoms include jaundice, pruritus, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The 
disease progresses rapidly, leading to the development of cirrhosis. Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to 
large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node 
enlargement.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are sent for active field surveillance of malnourished children to a rural district in central 
India. Which of the following specific finding would prompt you to make a diagnosis of 
marasmus?
questions.explanation:
Children with marasmus have a voracious appetite, whereas children with kwashiorkor often 
refuse to eat. Marasmus is a calorie deficit state and kwashiorkor is a protein deficit state. The signs of low 
protein manifesting as hypoalbuminemia and edema are characteristically seen in kwashiorkor.

questions.question:
Question 9: Sheila, a widowed maid brings her youngest child to your OPD with complaints of cough and 
cold. She has not been able to feed her kids after the lockdown affected her work. The image 
of the child is shown below. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case? 119 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows a child with marasmus which is not associated with apathy. Apathy is a 
psychomotor change seen in kwashiorkor.

questions.question:
Question 10: Shubham, a young infant was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of 11cms. On 
examination, the child appeared stunted with loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous tissue 
including the buccal pad of fat. What is the grade of marasmus in this child?
questions.explanation:
Wasting of buccal pad of fat is classified as grade 4 marasmus. Grading of marasmus (depending on wasting) Grading of kwashiorkor (depending on edema) 126

questions.question:
Question 11: A child from an urban slum area is admitted to your unit and is receiving treatment for 
Kwashiorkor. Which of the following is not true regarding the treatment?

options.c: Suspect primary treatment failure if appetite is not regained by day 4
options.d: Suspect secondary treatment failure if oedema reappears after 4 weeks

questions.explanation:
In a child with kwashiorkor, iron therapy (3 mg/kg/day) should be started only once the child 
starts gaining weight. Iron should not be given in the stabilization phase because excess iron can 
lead to free radical formation. The image below explains the treatment protocol to be followed in the case of PEM. The following should strike a suspicion of treatment failure in PEM: 127 
Sold by @itachibot Inpatient cases: Outpatient cases: Primary Failure

3 consecutive days during re

questions.question:
Question 12: A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatment 
in your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrect 
statements.
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14. The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases: Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions 
and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment. Mnemonic: SHIELDED • Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) • Hypothermia • Infection • ELectrolyte imbalance • DEhydration • Deficiency of nutrients Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks. Steps: • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 
5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed) • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo 
technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide 
indirect heat. • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration 
solution for malnutrition. 128 
Sold by @itachibot • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess 
sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 
weeks. • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children. • Correct micronutrient deficiencies: • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give 
iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase. • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1) • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day) • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day) • Start cautious feeding: Give ù to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that 
contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made 
which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, 
calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day. • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the 
return of appetite. • Beginning of feeding. • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.question:
Question 13: A 3 year old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of multiple episodes of loose 
stools and progressive weight loss. She was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of 
10.5 cm. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this child?

options.b: Administer 10 mL of 50% glucose IV, if unconscious
options.c: Continue aggressive hydration, even after dehydration resolves
options.d: Use ReSoMal for rehydration 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours

questions.explanation:
129 
Sold by @itachibot Progressive weight loss and mid-upper arm circumference of <11.5 cm denote severe acute 
protein-energy malnutrition (PEM). When accompanied by loose stools, management includes the 
use of low sodium ORS for rehydration of 5ml/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours. Management of fluid/electrolyte status in SAM: • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock. • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the 
first 2 hr orally or NG tube. • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss 
and eagerness to drink. Feed every other alternate hour. • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy. • Do not continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves. Treatment of hypoglycemia in malnutrition: • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL) orally or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue, whichever is the 
quickest. • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV. Note: 50% glucose is never used in children as it is extremely viscous and concentrated. This could lead 
to injection site pain, severe thrombophlebitis, and irritation. Also, this can cause osmotic 
overload in a three-year-old.

questions.question:
Question 14: A young girl who was grossly emaciated and undernourished was started on partial parenteral 
nutrition together with enteral nutrition via a nasogastric tube. In the first week, which 
among the following would be the hallmark for the development of refeeding syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia. Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are 
undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral 
alimentation. When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels 
may produce the following: • Hypophosphatemia (hallmark) • Hypokalemia • Hypomagnesemia A controlled transition over 3 days from F-75 to F-100 is recommended by the WHO for treating 
malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome. 130 
Sold by @itachibot Deficiency of Fat Soluble Vitamins
